title: If something is 'so bad it's good', is it good or is it still bad? - Quora

response.answer_text: Well, both.. It’s still bad, but good in a different respect. You’d be referring to different aspects of the thing. Take for example a terribly offensive joke, but one that is absolutely hilarious. It is bad insofar as it is detrimental to people or making light of something that ought to be taken seriously, but good insofar as it succeeds at doing what a joke does, which is making us laugh because of a certain incongruity or cleverness. It seems something “so bad it’s good” usually refers to humor. Aristotle called humor “a species of the ugly.” Ugly, meaning, things are not as they are supposed to be. (I’d add that humor includes cleverness, which would mean something being unusually good, the key being “unusual.”) We laugh at things because of their extraordinary badness or goodness. If we see something performed very badly, it becomes good humor. But good humor might also be something performed so well that it surprises you. In both cases, there is “ugliness” in the general sense—that things are not as they usually are. This dual nature of humor makes it something like a consolation prize for the ugliness of the world.

Good is defined as something that provides the greatest good on the greatest number of aspect of life and Bad is defined as something that provides the least good on the greatest number of aspects of life. Therefore, killing a lethal virus is good and killing a baby is bad. And creating a lethal virus is bad and creating a baby is good. This is the Universal standard of evaluation of Good and Bad.
